Description: For each leak, the time between leak detection and first device activation measures how quickly the system converts a detected leak into an alert or action.
Short rationale: Mostly measures system responsiveness; weak indirect link to whether humans ever see/act on alerts.

Description: The time between first device activation and the last leak detection record for that incident estimates how long the leak remained active after being flagged.
Short rationale: Tightly tied to how long users (or operators) take to fix issues after alerts, i.e., response behavior.

Description: Leak events in history that have no corresponding device activation in a reasonable time window are unalerted leaks and indicate alert-layer failure.
Short rationale: Indicates alert-layer failure; structural/system quality, not user behavior.

Description: Device activations that occur without any leak recorded around the same time and location indicate false or test alerts rather than true incidents.
Short rationale: Identifies false or test alerts; about configuration/noise, not people.

Description: Combining leak history with device activation history reconstructs a full incident timeline: when the leak started, when alerts fired, and when it was resolved.
Short rationale: Builds full incident timelines; can indirectly reveal when humans intervene but is mainly structural incident metadata.

Description: For leaks where a shutoff device activates, a sharp reduction or cessation of subsequent leak records shows that automatic shutoff is effective.
Short rationale: Device performance during leaks; no behavioral dimension.

Description: Very short detection-to-activation intervals suggest automated actions, while longer and more variable intervals indicate manual user responses.
Short rationale: Explicitly separates automatic vs manual actions, exposing patterns of human response timing.

Description: Comparing alert activation times with the times leaks stop provides a measure of how quickly users typically react to leak alerts.
Short rationale: Direct metric for how quickly users typically act on alerts to stop leaks.

Description: Leaks that only stop after multiple device activations show that a single alert is insufficient and that escalation helps drive mitigation.
Short rationale: Evaluates escalation logic; technical, not personal.

Description: If many device activations correspond to small, short-lived leaks, the system may be over-alerting, increasing the risk that users begin to ignore alerts.
Short rationale: Shows that small leaks trigger many alerts; doesn’t itself encode user behavior.

Inference: Prioritization of zones by unmitigated leak time
Description: Summing leak durations in which there was no or very delayed device activation yields unmitigated leak time per zone, highlighting where mitigation is weakest.
Short rationale: Highlights zones where leaks stay unmitigated; zone-level risk and policy, mild behavior signal.

Description: Locations with many leaks but few or no device activations indicate poor coverage by alarms or actuators in those areas.
Short rationale: Reveals which locations are under-instrumented; property layout/policy info.

Description: Zones with many device activations but very few leaks suggest over-instrumentation or overly sensitive triggers.
Short rationale: Zones with many alerts but few leaks; about design/tuning.

Inference: Leak severity vs. alert behavior alignment
Description: Severe leaks that receive only minimal or delayed device activations reveal misalignment between incident severity and the strength or speed of alerting.
Short rationale: Shows misalignment between severity and response; mostly system configuration, not identity.

Description: Device activations that recur at regular intervals and never coincide with leak entries can be identified as system tests rather than real leak events.
Short rationale: Regular test patterns expose maintenance/ops schedules (weak temporal behavior signal).

Description: If leak history shows a new leak at the same location soon after device activation marked resolution, the underlying problem was not fully fixed.
Short rationale: Indicates incomplete fixes; maintenance quality only.

Description: Devices whose activations are frequently followed by leak termination are more impactful, while those that rarely precede resolution may be less effective or misused.
Short rationale: Device effectiveness metric; no behavioral info.

Inference: Optimizing alert timing from historical patterns
Description: By comparing detection times, activation times, and leak durations, the system can learn optimal alert timing for different leak patterns to minimize damage.
Short rationale: Uses history to tune alert timing; system-level.

Description: If one device activation corresponds to multiple leak events in a short window, the system may be grouping multiple leaks as one broader incident.
Short rationale: Classifies event grouping; structural metadata.

Description: Leaks that last long or recur without triggering escalated device actions highlight where additional or stronger alerts should have been used.
Short rationale: Shows where escalation should have happened; policy/design issue.

Description: Leaks occurring at certain times of day may show longer detection-to-alert or alert-to-resolution gaps, indicating time-dependent differences in user availability.
Short rationale: Time-of-day patterns (e.g., slower response at night) give mild info about user availability/attention.

Inference: Validating leak detector accuracy via alert consistency
Description: Leak sensors that often produce leak events without any associated device activation may be mis-integrated into the alerting logic.
Short rationale: Flags mis-integrated sensors; technical integration.

Inference: Device malfunction detection using leak outcomes
Description: If device activations occur during leaks but leak records do not shorten or cease afterward, the corresponding device may be malfunctioning or improperly installed.
Short rationale: Detects malfunctioning devices; no user behavior.

Description: Some device activations may occur before any leak history entries and later correlate with fewer or milder leaks, indicating effective proactive protection.
Short rationale: Distinguishes pre-emptive from reactive device actions; system behavior only.

Description: The longest leak duration in history that occurred without any device activation represents the system’s current tolerance for silent leaks.
Short rationale: Longest unalerted leak duration; global risk tolerance metric, not personal.

Inference: Alignment between incident classification and device response
Description: If leaks classified as critical receive the same device response as minor leaks, the system is not using severity information to modulate alert strength.
Short rationale: Checks if severity labels affect response; policy-level.

Description: Comparing high-value or sensitive locations in leak history with their device activation patterns reveals whether they receive preferential, faster, or stronger responses.
Short rationale: Reveals whether high-value/sensitive locations get preferential protection; location/policy, not per-person.

Inference: Impact of configuration changes over time
Description: Before and after rule or configuration changes, shifts in the ratio of leaks with timely device activations and average leak duration reveal the impact of those changes.
Short rationale: Before/after config change impact; admin/system metric.

Description: Leaks that end faster when multiple devices activate together, compared to single-device responses, demonstrate the value of coordinated multi-device mitigation.
Short rationale: Compares single vs multi-device responses; technical only.

Description: If device activations such as automatic shutoff occur but leak records show continuity or quick recurrence, users may be overriding or bypassing protection mechanisms.
Short rationale: Directly reveals cases where users bypass or override protection (a clear behavioral/attitude signal).
